channel.title: Text colour above head when spoke
channel.description:
hello, i have been having a little problem. when ever i talk the text colour is red and uses the shake:.
i have looked in client class for ages but cannot find where it is.
if anyone could tell me what i need to search to change the colour.
any help.
thanks,

item.title: Text colour above head when spoke
item.dc:creator: @xxlukexx xxlukexx
item.description:
@xxlukexx wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:2, topic:276628”]alright… first things first… YOU DONT OPEN CLASS FILES… i dont get why all u noobs keep thinking u do… but yea… to the txt colors…

FILE EDITING: Client.java
DIFFICULY: 1/10 if u have a brain…

Step 1:

open your client.java and search for (this may vary a bit if your client already has a color or action for the txt…

int j2 = 0; int i3 = 0;

step 2:

Search a little further down and you will see some codes like

if(s.startsWith(“yellow:”))
{
j2 = 0;
aString887 = aString887.substring(7);
} else
if(s.startsWith(“red:”))
{
j2 = 1;
aString887 = aString887.substring(4);
} else
if(s.startsWith(“green:”))
{
j2 = 2;
aString887 = aString887.substring(6);
} else
if(s.startsWith(“cyan:”))
{
j2 = 3;
aString887 = aString887.substring(5);
} else
if(s.startsWith(“purple:”))
{
j2 = 4;

and under all that might be more colors… and or some animations…it all depends on your client.

step 3:
change the j2 and i3 int values to the ones you need
lets say you want white txt… you would do this to that code

[quote]
the j2 code is for the color of the txt… the i3 code is for the action. this stuff gets to be simple as people go but obiously nobody ever uses he ctrl+f command to search a file anymore… and thinks they much open class files… all a class file is, is a compiled java file. As long as your compiler acually works for you, you shouldnt need to EVER touch a class file
int j2 = 5; int i3 = 0;
[/quote][/quote]

ok, im gunna try that but first, why do you say that. just because i said client class u think i mean client.class but infact, client class is the same as client.java.

people who know java abit use client class.

also, when i go into client class and i search it, nothing comes up…

FIXED. ty for the codes.

Read full topic
item.source: Text colour above head when spoke

item.title: Text colour above head when spoke
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

alright… first things first… YOU DONT OPEN CLASS FILES… i dont get why all u noobs keep thinking u do… but yea… to the txt colors…

FILE EDITING: Client.java
DIFFICULY: 1/10 if u have a brain…

Step 1:

open your client.java and search for (this may vary a bit if your client already has a color or action for the txt…

int j2 = 0; int i3 = 0;

step 2:

Search a little further down and you will see some codes like

if(s.startsWith("yellow:")) { j2 = 0; aString887 = aString887.substring(7); } else if(s.startsWith("red:")) { j2 = 1; aString887 = aString887.substring(4); } else if(s.startsWith("green:")) { j2 = 2; aString887 = aString887.substring(6); } else if(s.startsWith("cyan:")) { j2 = 3; aString887 = aString887.substring(5); } else if(s.startsWith("purple:")) { j2 = 4;
and under all that might be more colors.. and or some animations...it all depends on your client.

step 3:
change the j2 and i3 int values to the ones you need
lets say you want white txt… you would do this to that code

the j2 code is for the color of the txt... the i3 code is for the action. this stuff gets to be simple as people go but obiously nobody ever uses he ctrl+f command to search a file anymore.. and thinks they much open class files... all a class file is, is a compiled java file. As long as your compiler acually works for you, you shouldnt need to EVER touch a class file int j2 = 5; int i3 = 0;

Read full topic
